#define errno /* implementation-defined */

{{c|errno}} is a preprocessor macro used for error indication. It expands to a {{rev inl|until=c++11|static}}{{rev inl|since=c++11|thread-local}} modifiable lvalue of type {{c/core|int}}.

Several standard library functions indicate errors by writing positive integers to {{c|errno}}. Typically, the value of {{c|errno}} is set to one of the error codes, listed in {{header|cerrno}} as macro constants that begin with the letter {{tt|E}}, followed by uppercase letters or digits.

The value of {{c|errno}} is {{c|0}} at program startup, and although library functions are allowed to write positive integers to {{c|errno}} whether or not an error occurred, library functions never store {{c|0}} in {{c|errno}}.
